posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

The "ban" is 12 years in the future, only applies to sales of new vehicles, and ICE range extenders for PHEVs are still allowed.

If there needs to be some exception made down the road there's more than enough time to do it, but for the moment the law is meant to be a wake up call to Western car manufacturers that they need to invest in keeping up technologically because tax payers will not be bailing them out this time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Long ago I spent a good chunk of my life working on vintage aircraft, and we used marvel quite extensively.

A buddy of mine was a director of maintenance up in Alaska on a couple DC-3s that got flown pretty hard.
At one point he had to swap out both engines on one of the '3s at the same time. It's pretty unusual to have two new engines on a plane like that. Usually you want to stagger them, for reliability and cost.
I suggested that he run an experiment with marvel. So he ran the left engine with marvel in the oil, and the right without. All 4 fuel tanks usually had some marvel in it. He ran this experiment for quite a while.

After the first year he started seeing the difference. Around the second year there was a night and day difference between the two engines.
The right engine had about the normal amount of sludge built up inside, but the left engine was insanely clean. It had higher compression, had a faster response to RPM changes because the prop governor and prop dome weren't sludged up, the engine oil temp was slightly lower because the oil cooler wasn't sludged up as well. Also, the left engine had lower oil consumption at only a 1/4 gal per hour, compared to the right at 3/4 gal per hour.

If you have a new engine, it's good to run marvel through the oil. But if it's a mid or high time engine, be prepared to change filters frequently for a while as the filters will fill up with all the crud that breaks loose.

Marvel in the fuel cleans the fuel system and helps preserve rubber seals.
We had to use them on the B-25 and DC-3 because of the rubber diaphragms in the pressure carbs.

Most importantly of all, it smells pretty good.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26232529
Pickups benefited from one of the most successful lifestyle marketing campaigns ever devised by man, right below religious salvation, human rights, representative democracy, infinite compound growth, and unlimited borrowing into the future. It used to be that people bought them for the rugged appearance, bigger than you crash safety, and tough "get out of my way" looks, a popular persona adopted by frustrated commuters that are ten minutes late to work already.

These days people just want trucks, because they want trucks. The circular logic has now been firmly embedded into the public to the point where they don't really have a good reason beyond that. It's an extension of their identity, as evidenced by the immense aftermarkets available to personalize them.

Now, a few people do buy them for utility, but you won't find them in downtown Atlanta or the outer suburbs of LA. They're way out yonder in the middle of nowhere, where the only way to traverse the land reliably, no matter rain, sleet, snow, or apocalypse, is with a AWD or 4x4.

Personally, I like them, but wouldn't want to own one. They do make driving in 40+ mph crosswinds in the middle of a Midwest winter blizzard a lot easier though. Doing that in a compact car is an exercise in attrition, and General Winter always wins.

>>26226713
I believe vans are much more practical for city use than trucks. You can haul around deliveries or your equipment while it's safely secured in an enclosed cabin and not an open tray like pickups. Larger vans tend to have better cargo room than most pickup trucks, especially those half-ton crew cabs with short useless beds. This is why it's highly preferable to own a van if your doing labor work.

Pickup trucks are practical in some degree as well. They tend to have a higher towing capacity, their beds can be modified to your liking such as replacing it with a dropside/flatbed (pic related) which frees up more space than an ordinary fleetside bed, and you can haul stuff that you wouldn't dare put in the inside of your cabin like dirt, sand or something that shouldn't be inhaled. The only other big advantage they have over vans is towing large gooseneck trailers, which is beneficial for most farmers or ranchers, keep in mind those trucks are usually duallies.

t. truck guy

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226713
Loading/unloading pickups is much easier but weather matters (a lot).

I transport outsize and heavy items which a van body would make much less convenient to load when it permitted that at all, and a box truck body is annoying to drive because shit visibility while acting like a drag chute thus killing fuel mileage. I can easily have engines and transmissions forklifted into my pickups after harvesting them at salvage. I can easily ride motorbikes up my ramp or have ample room to winch them on dollies. I can easily carry outsize steel and other building supplies. Only bridge height limits what I can fit in a pickup.

Vans offer weather and theft protection, neither are big deals to me and I also have a box trailer and a dual axle car trailer. If van or box truck worked better I'd add one to the fleet. They do not for my specific use case. Only specifics matter.

Things either should have include Tommy Gate style liftgates which are cheap used, simple and easy to install. Many pickup users like the advantage of specialty service bodies which permit external mounting of generators, compressors and engine-driven welders. Flammable gas cylinders should be mounted externally for safety. The result is why typical service trucks look as they do, but box trucks can serve with some work.

Northern Europe has little but rainy weather so vans or box trucks are mandatory, and theft is a constant concern in urban areas anywhere. In that case get a van or box body. Note box bodies hold more than vans and mount to pickup chassis (though some have partial cabs based on van parts.

Americans being rich can afford motorbikes and jet skis which trucks are much more convenient to carry. It's still legal to burn wood here and trucks are easier to load, unload and clean. Transporting mowers etc is convenient by pickup so I do.

>>26231373
Yes, it is. It's not that different from a regular W211 except for the engine which is reliable, much more reliable that the M156 that succeeded it.
The trans is an old 5-speed auto that can withstand 1000+ NM.
The air suspension is finicky, but not too expensive to fix.
You do get electrical gremlins, the heated/ventilated seats on mine don't work and I'm in the process of getting some electrical wiring and stuff from other W211s to fix it.
Also it consumes a bit of oil, but I'm not too worried since it was a bargain basically.
I love it, the torque is brutal, the acceleration is great, it's going toe to toe with much newer and more powerful cars. Did a dragy run when I bought it and it got 10s for 100-200km/h.
Though you need grip, powerful 4x4 will beat you from a standstil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26233381
I can't speak for the M3. But truth be told, the E46 is much more confidence inspiring. It feels a heck of a lot more planted and refined compared to the BRZ. It also helps the the non-M e46's have comparatively longer wheel bases and are open diff, making them a hell of a lot less twitchy compared to the BRZ. Steering feed back is fantastic due to the nature of hydraulic assist. But that said, the BRZ just feels overall better and more fun, Especially after you do headers and a flash tune to eliminate the dreaded torque dip. That said, if you like small low power cars to throw around, its an absolute riot compared to the e46. Me being fidgety makes throwing the car into gears really fun because of the really short gear ratio. The e46 around town comparatively feels boring because of its longer gearing. Both clutches are lightweight, so traffic isnt an issue, but the e46 also feels a hell of a lot more numb and sluggish. Shift feel in the BRZ is way better, e46 is sloppy like all BMWs of that era Honestly, I've been trying to modify the e46 to feel more like the BRZ, and that says something. Seating position on both cars is great compared to other cars. but in the e46 it feels like you sit too damn high and the steering wheel angle makes it feel like you're driving a semi.The BRZ is perfect out of the box. The seats are comfortable, and the pedals, steering wheel and shifter are all perfectly positioned. I havent tracked the E46 yet, and by the time the car is ready, i feel like it will be too damn heavily modified to give an accurate representation of stock vs stock.. The BRZ has its flaws, but the overall is a way better platform. Its much lighter stock, 2800 vs 3300lbs. And the chassis is stiffer right out of the box. The E46 is the better all rounder and a better daily. The chassis has potential, but its overall structurally too weak for abuse. You'd spend a lot of money reinforcing it and taking weight out of a car is much harder than adding power.

Come join us this Saturday for the triple header special, a competition in 3 legs across 2 games testing speed and navigation skills.
First leg is an AC nordschleife snow race in the pikes peak cars, the fastest cars we have ever raced before. They are capable of around 6 minute lap times so sharpen up.
Then load the cars up in your trailer, take the wheel of your truck, and move from Cologne to Palermo in ETS2 with no navigation aids beyond a map and your skill at reading road signs.
Once at the Targa Florio, take the other car you prepared and try not to die around the long and treacherous vintage test.

Sign ups (put a link for your car for leg 3 if its not kunos stock content) and more infos on mods needed on the google doc

>>26234316
The non joke answer that doesn't involve games released 15 years ago is GRID: Legends for some sort of "motorsport progression" experience, Gran Turismo 7 is a bit of a disappointment if you're out for the Gran Turismo experience but it's not a bad game, Project Cars 2 if you want a slightly more simulator tier approach and a long career more spanning several types of car and track. Finally the Codies F1 games and Dirt Rally 2.0 are probably the best "single discipline" racing games but you may get bored of doing the same thing over and over. Whatever floats your boat there. Wreckfest is another really good option for racing something a bit more "random" like shitboxes and lawn mowers but genuinely fun.

For older games, Race07 is genuinely a great game to play but it is older and you'll need ALL DLC to have fun. The first GRID Game is also very good.

Finally for literally "racing" games WipEout is my personal favorite, alternatively RedOut 1 (not 2) and BallisticNG on PC are very good spiritual successors.

Assetto Corsa is only a good single player game if all you want to do is hotlap, drift and take screenshots. The AI is complete and utter garbage and even a reasonably slow driver will run circles around them. AMS2 is a scam at best. AMS1 is just reskinned rFactor (2005) and really only good for multiplayer (where it shines). Assetto Corsa Competizione has slightly better AI but the game is just so god damn boring to drive in my opinion and it takes a nuclear reactor of a PC to play. rFactor 2 is kinda ok for singleplayer but only on official tracks. Most usermade tracks confuse the AI and you'll run circles around them.

please nothing mundane or dumb, bonus if you came up with it even if not necessarily original.

one I've been pondering for a while is to add a cylinder pressure sensor and use the resulting crank angle vs pressure data to adjust ignition timing real-time while driving to adjust for AFR, base pressure, octane, etc in order to get the best (most power) timing on the threshold of knock at all times.
in addition, one can do a little bit of integration of this pressure signal and measure the engine's current cylinder output power, to better compare any tuning tweaks. street tuning made better? dyno not needed?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26231837
The main differences are the engine and transmission options. By and large its the same car throughout the years. Early years have a fully hydraulic controlled 4 speed automatic, later models got a "sealed for life" 5 speed but everyone services them anyway. That same 5 speed was used by mercedes deep into the 2010s because no transmission they had could handle the torque of the newer engines.
You could buy a few models of straight 6 over the years (even manual in the very early cars) and a v12 was added in 1992. Up until 1998, the v8 models had the 32v dohc 5.0 m119 (sauber c9, road car version) which was then replaced by the 24v sohc m113 - considered by many to be mercedes best engine. No matter what model you pick, they're all fantastic and reliable engines with a lot to enjoy. There's more minute differences between late and early but nothing too significant. Some models before 96 were affected by the infamous biodegradable harnesses but most have been replaced or junked by now.
Some people will argue in favor of the early cars, some later. The key is getting a car thats been maintained in good condition as they are all excellent.

>>26233276
People consider it a downgrade on stats but the street performance is the same. The m113 makes less hp but it's lighter, simpler, and more efficient (if it matters). The m113 has more low end torque, the m119 needs to be revved to really get the power.
In an m113 you don't have to deal with things like a water cooled intake manifold. The m113 does have 16 plugs, but they're easy to do and part of why m113s can run for so long. You also have a simpler valvetrain and timing system.
The purists will obviously prefer the 32v for the heritage but I'm just fine with the later engine.

What's fascinating for me is the sheer variety of machines during this era of sports car racing. Especially in the early days of BPR and Le Mans before the manufacturers flooded in.
In GT1 you had oddities like
>Aston Martin DB7 LM GT1
>Bugatti EB110SC
>Callaway C7R
>Chevy Corvette C4 ZR-1
>De Tomaso Pantera GT1
>Jaguar XJ220C
>Lotus Esprit GT1
>Nissan 300ZX IMSA
>Renault Spider GT1
>Porsche 911 GT2 Evo

And over in GT2, you have even weirder shit
>Callaway Supernatural Corvette LM
>Ferrari 348 and 355s
>Marcos LM600
>Morgan Plus 8 GTR
>Saleen Mustang GT2
>VBM 4000 GTC
>Venturi 400/500/600LM

Half of them weren't anywhere near competitive against the F40s and later the Mclaren F1s but it's interesting to see what smaller teams would throw together in a shitbox to try and make them work.
It's sad that something like this will probably never be replicated again.

Whoever this is is moron talking out of his ass and doesn't understand that technical regulations don't stay static for decades. Rules change and cars can be eligible for different categories. The McLaren F1 didn't race under the same GT1 regs in 1997 as it did in the years prior. The Toyota GT-One was recategorized as a GTP when GT1 was cancelled. The Viper GTS/R raced as a GT1 in its first year, then rehomologated as a GT2. It'd also race under the IMSA/ACO rules in the GTS category. Then you had the Maserti MC-12 which didn't conform to re-vamped GT1 regs of mid-'00s, but was granted homologation on a waiver anyway because Mosley demanded it.

The main takeaway is that rules change and different racing series can categorize cars as they see fit. GT1 in 1994 was not the same as GT1 in 2005 or GTS in 2001 or GT in 2003. They are all different rule sets.

>>26194439
>>26194907
The desolation in sportscar racing caused by the subsequent collapse of Gr.C (and Gr.B a few years before) led to fans looking at more national-level and single-make series to get their fix. Under these circumstances, Venturi made their own one-make series in 1992 called the Gentleman Driver's Trophy for amateurs which garnered a lot of attention despite being side-events for bigger races. The series used their 400 Trophy racecar and got a lot of response from teams. In charge of the series was Venturi's head of competition services, Stephane Ratel, who is practically the godfather of the modern GT era. In 1993, facing a dwindling prototype field, the ACO allowed production-based cars to fill the rest of the grid for the first time since 1986. The response to their Trophy series and a chance for competing at the LM24, Venturi stepped up to the plate with the 500LM and were represented by no less than 7 cars. They didn't win, but most of the cars actually succeeded in finishing the race.

In 1994, Ratel teamed up with Jurgen Barth and Patrick Peter to make the BPR series which would aim to become the first intercontinental sportscar series since Gr.C folded. Ratel would apply his connections from the Trophy series to get teams to race in BPR giving Venturi a strong presence in a field that would otherwise be a slew of 911s and a single F40 for most of the races. The BPR would continue to grow in 1995 and 1996 with Venturi competing every year until it was taken over by the FIA. During the BPR years Ratel would form the SRO which has been shaping GT racing for almost 30 years.

>>26195544
First, nice Double-Dubs.

Second, something to add was that the performance spike and extremely high running costs of Group C & GTP cars in America in the early 1990s lead to many privateer teams and gentlemen drivers to look elsewhere, which in turn lead to a rise in One-Make series like the Porsche Super Cup and the Ferrari Challenge series. The head if Porsche's competition department at the time? Jurgen Barth.

The biggest mover and shaker in the Ferrari Challenge series when it launched in the 1990s? Patrick Peter.

By early 1993, Stephane Ratel, Barth and Peter started organizing special race weekends where teams in their one-make series that were up for it raced against each other. By Le Mans that year, the BPR GT series was starting to take shape and they just so happened to use the rulebook Le Mans came up with for 1994.

>>26196450
I think Peter's clout back in the '90s was promoting events, especially vintage motorsport. Before BPR, his organization brought back the modern interpretation of the French Tour Auto event in 1992. He would later go on to start the Le Mans Classic in the early-'00s. His connection was useful in filling up the grid as many teams were just amateur drivers that owned or maintained classic racecars.

Barth was basically just famous for his career as a Porsche factory driver having 4 class wins at LM24 with one of those being an outright win in a 936. He was just there to put a famous face on the series and his final class win happened just months before the first BPR race. Essentially the spokesman, he held a lot of celebrity sway over Porsche enthusiasts (and probably why so many teams on the grid were driving Porsches)

Ratel was the main guy running the whole operation. He also used his connections at Venturi to get teams from the Trophy series to sign on to BPR and step up the Trophy cars to one of the new 500LM racecars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Jesus Christ, too many normies in this thread flinging shit at each other without actually knowing whose shit it is.

The GTS/R originally raced as a GT1 car when it debuted in 1996. Back then the main deciding factor of which category a car belonged was based on engine displacement. The Viper being 8.0L was firmly designated for GT1. When the FIA revised their rules for 1997 (mainly to allow for more exotic cars and technology like the CLK GTR), Chrysler had the GTS/R rehomologated for FIA's GT2. For the US races, they would race under the SCCA's GT2 category for USRRC races and IMSA/ACO's GTS category for ALMS. When USRRC gave way to Grand-Am, the GTS/R was in the GTO category until they renamed it GTS (many of the same cars as ACO, but under GARRA's rules) until Vipers were no longer running in the series. These different categories in different series were basically analogous to FIA's pre-'97 regs.

When ACO adopted the FIA's newly revised GT regs essentially adapting the old GTS and GT classes as new GT1 and GT2, the GTS/R was categorized as a GT1 under the new rules. By adopting the ACO's GTS rules, in a round-about way, the FIA returned to GT1 back to what it was before the 1997 changes.

>>26190935
That's the 1999 D24. That event was part of the USRRC in those days which ran under the SCCA rules. Under those rules, the C5-R (and the EMR Corvette) was categorized as a GT2 which was a ported version of FIA GT1 for the US. So the "GT2" decal on the car does denote the category car is racing in because it's an SCCA GT2 which is different from FIA GT2.

>>26190497
The story of the 911 GT1 is a silly one. The only reason why Porsche got into GT1 in the first place was because their 1995 prototype project fell through and ACO banned them from racing a 962 in a GT category after '94. Instead of complying with the rules of not entering a prototype in a GT class, they would build a new prototype and have the rules changed later and so they came out with the 911 GT1 for '96. They'd win some races in BPR, but because it wasn't homologated at the time, it didn't count for any championship points. When the FIA took over BPR and updated the rules, irony Porsche as it was getting beaten at their own game by the new Mercedes and updated McLaren. For most of the program, the car was getting its butt-kicked in FIA GT and could only muster a few non-championship exhibition races. Their only consolation prize was a championship in the national-level BGTC.

It was in 1998 that they went go-for-broke in the final year of the program and completely revised the car. They still got their ass handed to them in FIA GT (and lost their BGTC crown to a McLaren team), but they did end up winning Le Mans. However to do it, Porsche had to buyout the LMP team that had been beating them over the last two years and "upgrade" their cars. Both would DNF leaving the GT1 cars the sole factory-supported team. The biggest irony was that the LMP car that kept beating them before was the using Porsche's abandoned prototype project from before.

The final black eye of the program was at the final race of the factory program at the very first Petite Le Mans where they DNF'd by managing to get the car airborne and flip over end-over-end.

A stupid end to a stupid car.

>I’d argue the absurd performance gap the McLaren F1 had when it started racing against other road cars is what led to the batshit stuff like the GT-One and CLK-lm
Nope. The F1 GTR was perfectly compliant with the GT1 regs at the time. The performance gap was because McLaren was the only manufacturer focusing on GT1 at the time and the car just being a better car than everybody else.

The 911 GT1 was not eligible for homologation under the then-current rules when it debuted in 1996 hence why it did not score any championship points. Porsche had to wait for the new rules the following year for the car to be properly homologated. It was that rule change, initiated by Porsche, that led to the prototype GT1 cars.

I understand what you're saying about trying to determine what is normal wear and tear for a used bike. It can be tough to tell, especially when you're still getting familiar with your own bike. And it's true that pictures can sometimes make things look better than they really are. However, it's important to remember that just because a bike may not look brand new, that doesn't necessarily mean it's a "shitbike." Every bike is going to show some signs of age and use, and that's completely normal. It's more important to focus on the condition and performance of the bike, rather than just its appearance. As long as it's well-maintained and running well, that's what really matters.

>>26232834
Hell no, kiwi-brother! You're absolutely right about the folding of steel. It does little to improve the strength of a motorcycle frame. In fact, it can even weaken the steel if it's folded too many times. The key is to use the right combination of different types of steel, with each layer chosen for its specific properties.

And you're right about the history of folding steel too. It was originally used to try to purify low-quality iron ore, but it doesn't really have any practical applications today. Only the most infantile would believe that everything the Japanese do is correct. There are certainly some things they do well, but there are also plenty of things that they don't do as well as other countries. It's important to recognize that no one has a monopoly on good ideas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26189184
>this car rarely revs up, it's always at around 2k or less RPMs
That's because you're driving a based Accord, doesn't need to rev a lot to do work, but they do sound very unhappy at high rpms, the whole cylinder head is setup to run below 2400 rpm with half the intake valves shut off while cruising in 5th gear.

posts.com:
>>26189191

>>26202738
I've owned 2 ashtray cars.
the car will always have a smell of stale tobacco, mainly during hot days but, you can get most of it out.
I copied the typical "disaster detail" steps you see in yt vids complete with seat removal, center console removal, deep vacuuming, soap, borax, and oxiclean solutions used with an extractor and drill brush on every soft surface.
the only spot I didn't hit super hard was the headliner because it was already weak in some areas.
even after all that it leeches out some stink in the summer heat. charcoal or baking soda cabin filter helps a lot if you run recirculation

it might be worth it if it isn't that bad and you can tolerate the smell.

>>26226861

Well, I'm at a point where I'm kind of regretting getting a car. Perhaps it's the moment to buy some tools and learn or die trying. I have to change on this car:

>VVT solenoid (or its gasket). Will the solenoid break when I take it out?
>VVT spool valve filter
>Oil pressure switch assembly

All these 3 leak oil according to the mechanic that checked the car. Also have to change:

>Shocks
>Rear brake pads

How feasible it is to do this if I haven't even done oil changes?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226906
I know it seems like the mechanic is trying to murder you with cost, but these are the things that do leak on Hondas, I even had VVT solenoid, the pressure switch, and the VTC strainer gasket leak myself. Since these cars are so reliable, I would check the oil every week or so depending on bad the car is leaking, and keep driving it to work, and fixing whatever you can afford to fix as you go about your business, whenever you get paid, buy some brake pads, whenever you get paid, buy a strut or two, and then keep saving and saving, until you can just show up at the shop and have everything done like I did, I would get a labor quote on everything, so that you know how much you need to save, a new Honda is breaking the bank, and then another used Honda is just gonna need the same things due to sheer age, so maybe fixing what you've got and continuing on as the rest of the car is healthy is a good idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26230793
Cheap rubber. Other causes:
1.Direct sunlight slowly dry rots the rubber.
2.Rubber of the wipers gets full of dirt, this is what increases the wear of the wiper blades. Wiping them clean with wet rag or paper occasionally makes them last a little bit longer but if you rather be lazy and dont want to clean wiper blades then one alternative is to take the whole car into carwash. Dirty wiper blades is also one reason why wipers can get noisy during operation despite wiper blades being fairly new condition.

Silicone wiper blades cost more money, but also last longer.

>>26230793
>Why do these fuckers last for such a short period ?

Mine lasted a long time whether it be in the desert states or the northern states where I am now. Whenever they lasted a short time, it was because I used them on a gritty rough windshield such as moving over ice frozen onto the windshield. Scrape the ice off and don't use the wipers to rub the ice off the windshield.

Wipers streak because that sharp even edge gets little abrasions from rubbing on hard gritty things like ice or bird poop with little sand grit in it. My current beam wipers I got in 2015 and I am still using the same ones. Only the right side has a slight streak in several places.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Black Volga (Polish: czarna wołga) refers to an urban legend widespread in Poland, Romania, Hungary, Russia, Belarus, Ukraine, Greece and Mongolia, mainly in the 1960s and 1970s. The legend refers to a black (or in some versions red) GAZ-21 or GAZ-24 that was allegedly used to abduct and murder people. According to different versions, it was driven by communist secret police, Russian mafia, Satanists or Satan himself. The car is described as having white wheel rims, white curtains or other white elements.

This impression was also caused by the active use of the passenger car of the Gorky Automobile Plant GAZ-M1 (Emka) by the NKVD bodies during the years of mass repression. For the sake of saving money, during almost all the time of its release, the M1 was only available with black paint, which emphasized the ominous image of the car.

Supposedly, victims were kidnapped and then murdered by the perpetrators to use their blood as a cure for rich Westerners or Arabs suffering from leukemia. Other variants used organ theft as the motive, combing it with another infamous legend of kidney theft by the KGB. The legend surfaced again in the late 20th century, with a BMW or Mercedes car taking the Volga's place. The Black Volga was sometimes depicted with horns instead of wing mirrors. It could also have the number "666" on the license plate, as well as having white windows or curtains. In this version, the driver (allegedly the devil) would ask passers-by for the time and kill them when they approached the car to answer. In another version of the legend, the victim would die at the same time a day later (the driver would say: "Tomorrow you will die at this hour"). However, there was an effective defence method—whenever the driver of the Black Volga asked "What time is it?", the person would have to answer "It is God's time". Then the car would quickly vanish.

In a "bold" attempt at shitbox dress shoe design, the 1947 Davis Divan was an attempt at the three-wheeled car that ultimately ended in a similar vein as the Reliant Robin did in the UK, just a good thirty years prior to what is called the "Fiberglass Pig."

Its main selling point was its extremely good fuel economy for the day due to it being lightweight, and its ability to do tight donuts at a circumference of around 17 ft thanks to its single front wheel design. Its flaws, should be obvious even if they're to be considered "design choices."

Around fifty remain from the original production line as of today. The OP's picture is from 2021 in Amelia Island, Florida where three Divan curators took their pieces of garbage to an airstrip to drag race at a blistering 50mph for a hundred dollar grand prize. The airport was well aware of the stunt and endorsed it.

Because it's funny.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26231387
You bought coilovers for a DD. They have parts like spherical bushings and pillow ball mounts that just don't take to road use.
Salt, dirt, whatever your tires decide to kick up from the road makes it's way onto whatever suspension components you're running.

Race tracks are incredibly clean compared to typical road surfaces and do not introduce the kind of debris that a daily driver will encounter on the road.

Depending on what car you're running, get a set of H&R coils with Koni shocks (adjustable dampening), it's a tried a true combo that Honda, VW, Miata, etc guys have used for years.

Short story: MOST coilovers aren't worth it unless you're shelling out for better stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226080
Electric AWD is easy to achieve, just put an electric motor/generator on the front axle, which is also optimal for use with KERS. For a PHEV like this, that motor generator should let them eliminate a lot of complexity from the gas range extender engine as well since it will no longer need a traditional alternator, and they'll almost certainly have electric climate control as well, like using a heatpump to move heat from the powertrain to the cabin.

AWD with a MR layout pure ICE car requires you to have a driveshaft going from the transmission at the rear forward to the front axle. Its a lot harder to engineer and you don't get any advantages from doing it that way.
You may not like it from a philosophical purity perspective, but PHEV really is the best solution today.

>>26233736
My issue with subaru after 2019 is their use of the massive tablet infotainment especially as they hide many controls behind that computer. This is exactly the opposite of their previous gens which had screens but all of the controls were still physical and the screen only controlled media stuff. My second issue is with the CVT. While Subaru has made strides in improving their CVT reliability my big issues have always been the inconsistent power delivery in questionable conditions. The CVT computer or computer systems as a whole are known to refuse to transmit power purely to prevent a high load from being transferred through the CVT. It'll either use TCS to reduce throttle or the TCU will disengage the torque converter. The engine will rev incessantly but none of that power makes it to the wheels.

At 38k USD thats a lot of money for the cheapest XT. Thats basically top trim for most other economy car makers. I would still prefer other cars like the Rav4 hybrid because its AWD system is just as good for any realistic scenario and it gets a fuck ton better gas mileage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been looking at part numbers, spec sheets and compatibility charts again.
Turns out the brake setup on the Espace 1/2 is very similar to the Clio Williams, which is identical to the one found on late 16V Twingos (same caliper mounting hole spacing, same brake disc diameter, they even take the same brake pads), but with one crucial difference: the Espace calipers get much bigger pistons (54mm vs 48mm).
They also cost less than 50 eurobucks a pop brand new. Might need a new master cylinder to compensate for the increased pedal travel but this is all very promising, it's not quite a big brake kit but it should all still just barely fit under 14" wheels and get you some extra stopping power.

Also if you upgrade to 15x6-7" wheels you can run Goodyear Eagle F1s in 195/45R15, which sounds hilarious for trackday sessions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226818
Oh and forgot to mention, if they work on the mk1 they should also work all the way up to the mk2 GT, the RS gets bigger discs and different 57mm calipers, from the Laguna I believe.

>>26231492
Lead Acid BEVs of the era were really great compared to a horse, and ICE vehicles at the time just weren't practical daily use vehicles around town because they needed constant attention from skilled mechanics, and they risked breaking bones every time they started them.
Basically just novelties for the wealthy to drive on weekends.

Ironically it was gas vehicles picking up electrical systems based on those 12v lead acid systems that made them more practical, something that the car enthusiasts of the time hated as the vehicles became something practical for the general public.
That combined with the Government subsidies for gasoline after the first world war is what killed off the older generation of EVs.

There were a few attempts at reviving EVs, mostly when the subsidy structure broke down and gas became scarce or too expensive, but they never worked out long term because of the fact that lead acid batteries couldn't store even the equivalent of one gallon of gasoline and so the minute the subsidies were restored gas cars took back over.
Now EVs are catching on even with the subsidies in place because lithium ion batteries even in very affordable cars can now store about the equivalent of 2 gallons.
There's just no reason for people who can afford a daily use car to not own a BEV or a PHEV today in that role.

The funny thing is this will restore ICE cars to their proper place as weekend enthusiast vehicles, but /o/ hates that idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26229840
Your tyre is the "suspension" for your cars suspension components. Driving without one removes all the shock absorption that protects those components.

In your case, you drove a mile. Not terrible, not great. You definitely need a tyre. You will need to have the inside of the wheel checked for buckling on a wheel balancer, that's 50/50 on wether or not it'll be damaged, depends on the wheel/road conditions you drove over.
Other than that, expect that damper/shock absorber to last half as long as the one on the other side.
They'll also need to check the wheel studs to ensure that rimming your car like a Basketball American didn't fatigue them.

Probably no reason to panic, but next time swap it for the spare.
You fucking ape.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26229840
Use insurance to get a tow to wherever you buy tires from. If you bought that set of tires currently on the vehicle and you have some sort of road hazard warranty, you're in luck. Take it to wherever you bought the tires from, get the claim taken care of, and enjoy your new tire. If not, a tire + installation at a dealership or tire shop chain will probably probably run you around $200 depending on what tire you buy.
Chances are you may have bent the wheel when you hit the pothole, more often than not a bent wheel is safe to repair. Find a local wheel repair business, most are mobile and will come to your car, leave it on a jackstand or spare wheel, and you'll have your wheel back in a day or so. May run you $75-$125 depending on who you hire. If you're really unlucky and the wheel is so bent that it won't hold air or that the wheel is cracked, get a new one. You can probably find a used one on Facebook Marketplace for around $100, just search "Ford Fusion wheel" and be sure that it's the same design with the same size tire. Or, you can order a brand new one from your local for dealer for I'm guessing $800

>>26230150
>What is unsprung weight.
No such thing as a stupid question, anon. Pretty much everything under the strut spring seat does not have road surface undulations absorbed by the suspension system.
These need to be strong enough to deal with that while not being too heavy to have their movement properly regulated by the dampers.
The tyre acts as their buffer zone between them and the road just as the suspension does between your car and the wheels on said road.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26231221
Inexpensive aluminum alloys from Dezent(better choice), Barzetta. Use locking lug bolts/nuts because these make it slower for thieves to steal rims and tires. If you dont do car repairs yourself then put the regular regular lug bolts/nuts back before you take the car to the repair shop. then after you get car back from repair shop the reinstall the locking lug bolts/nuts with regular wrench or torque wrench. This way the locking lug bolts/nuts last longer because they are not being opened or tightened with impact wrench too many times.

if you dont care about looks of the car, put a little bit of paint to the visible part of rims- or scatch the rim hubcaps little bit to make them less valuable. Then thieves are more likely to leave the rims alone because they cant get so much money from stealing and selling the rims.

>>26232012
Where you make full boost is not the only effect of turbo lag. For example, I had a BW S366 on my 2JZ back in the day. I got full boost around 4,700rpm if I did a dyno pull, but as an example if I were to start in 4th gear at 5,500rpm (rev limit was 7,200), it would still take around 2 seconds to build full boost if I just floored it. That's turbo lag, it still exists even if you're up around peak torque. As a result I would brake boost to roll race. That way I could load up and build some pressure and when I released the brakes I was already almost at full boost.

>>26232035
That's not a variable geometry turbo.

You may view the NA as a classic car and in many respects it is, not disagreeing with that. The thing is that the NA isn't treated nor is it seen as a classic car by most. Most see them as overpriced "muh JDM" tin cans. With that mentality, of course people are still going to treat as disposable. It's not just the Miata, it's most 90s cars in general sans halo cars.
The reason for this I attribute to a lack of cheap new sport cars. Realistically, the only cheap fun options left are the GR86, ND, and maybe the 2 Series if you're a massive cuck. So a lack of new cars to purchase, people hold on to old sport cars. What's unique about the 2020s though is because of a lack of options, cars which should have already gone through their disposable phase are still in that phase.
The NA Miata should have gone as a vintage classic around 6 years ago. It doesn't have that status and it probably won't have it for another 5 years. By then they should become rare enough where they can finally be seen as classics. Assuming that's how it goes, a car like the NA stayed in the disposable phase for 11 years.
It's just what happens when there aren't new cheap sport cars to trash
